{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3154377,"name":"Berkin","username":"brknarsy","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/53a042/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-28T15:24:31.291Z","cooked":"

Our team is testing ramsete command and trajectory following features. We were able to create a path and get constants from sysid. When we enable robot in autonomous mode, robot follows the correct path and ends in the right direction however it shakes and high voltages from shuffleboard are seen.

WhatsApp Image 2023-02-28 at 17.52.521920×1080 216 KB

We did sysid multiple times and we always got approximately same values .

WhatsApp Image 2023-02-28 at 17.45.451920×1080 228 KB

Here’s a reference video to make the problem clear:

We plotted the values we got from tank drive and we encountered something weird.

WhatsApp Image 2023-02-28 at 18.16.331599×899 156 KB

Can someone help?

What’s the signal chain like? What are your encoders, and how are they being processed?

We use SRX Magnetic Encoder and VictorSPX’s, our distance per pulse is set to wheel perimeter in meters / 1024
We update odometry with encoder.getDistance() in periodic

You may see better results if you decrease your sensor delay by lowering the velocity measurement window settings in the Talon API.

Can you share your SysId results?

WhatsApp Image 2023-02-28 at 18.33.53 (1)2048×1152 411 KB

This is our latest sysid results. Can you provide more info about Talon API?
By the way we use breakout board to read data from encoder. It is connected to dio in roborio.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-02-28T15:35:46.802Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":43,"readers_count":42,"score":13.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":428425,"topic_slug":"high-voltages-seen-while-trajectory-following","display_username":"Berkin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/3/a/3aba0d501b8c73a9941a9109b689cd7d4d1e3255.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12381,"username":"Oblarg","name":"Eli Barnett","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56296,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/high-voltages-seen-while-trajectory-following/428425/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3154395,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-28T15:39:39.432Z","cooked":"

Ah! High-resolution encoders interact badly with the WPILib encoder class when measuring velocity unless you increase the samplesToAverage setting high enough to wash out timing error in the FPGA clock (it measures time-per-tick, rather than ticks-per-time).

Try exponential-searching that setting in the upwards direction until most of that noise is gone. Otherwise, plug the encoder into the motor controller.
